TEXT: The applicants , Mr PERSON and PERSON , are NORP nationals who live in GPE , GPE .
The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .

The applicants own a flower stall . On DATE ORG ( PERSON ) ordered them to remove the stall from a public road , where they had located it without the required authorisation . The applicant ’s did not obey and , on DATE , the stall was removed and put into storage .
The applicants have not attempted to recover it .
On DATE the applicants sued the GPE before ORG ( Sąd Rejonowy ) , seeking compensation for their stall , which had allegedly been damaged .
On DATE the court dismissed the claim . It found that the applicants had wrongly sued the Municipality , as the party to the proceedings should have been the ORG Governor ( ORG ) .
On DATE ORG ( PERSON ) upheld the first instance judgment .
Due to the value of the claim , a cassation appeal was not available in this case .
On DATE the ORG PERSON ) issued a building permit in favour of PERSON and GPE , the applicants’ neighbours . They were to build an outhouse .
On DATE the ORG Governor ( ORG ) , upon the applicants’ appeal , upheld the contested decision .
On DATE ORG ( PERSON ) remitted the case .
The Governor upheld his original decision on DATE .
On DATE ORG declared that decision null and void .
On DATE the Governor again upheld his original decision .
It was quashed by ORG on DATE .
On DATE ORG ordered that PERSON and GPE make temporary arrangements to ensure the safety of the neighbouring house .
On DATE the ORG Governor upheld that decision .
The applicants appealed on DATE .
On DATE ORG gave judgment .
On DATE the Mayor of ORG ( PERSON ) ordered that the outhouse be demolished .
On DATE the ORG Governor upheld the first instance decision .
On DATE ORG dismissed GPE ’s and GPE ’s further appeal .
On DATE the Minister of ORG ( Minister PERSON i GPE ) refused the applicants’ GPE application for the annulment of the decisions of DATE and DATE .
On DATE ORG dismissed their appeal .
On DATE the applicants complained to ORG ( ORG ) about the fact that the outhouse had not been demolished .
In reply , the ORG informed them that enforcement proceedings would be initiated .
On DATE the applicants complained about inactivity on the part of ORG to the Mayor of ORG . They maintained that the demolition order of CARDINAL DATE had not been executed .
On DATE the Mayor replied that the applicants’ neighbours had been fined for non - compliance with the order , but the relevant authorities had failed to execute that decision .
On DATE the applicants complained to PERSON ( FAC ) about the inactivity of ORG .

On DATE the ORG ( Powiatowy Inspektor Nadzoru Budowlanego w GPE ) informed the applicants that , since their neighbours had failed to demolish the outhouse , a so - called “ vicarious ” execution ( wykonanie zastępcze ) of the demolition order would be carried out .
On DATE ORG issued a decision ordering the vicarious execution .
On DATE PERSON ( Kujawsko - Pomorski Wojewódzki Inspektor PERSON ) upheld that decision .
On DATE ORG dismissed PERSON ’s and PERSON ’s further appeal .
It appears that the demolition has not been carried out to date .

At the material time section CARDINAL of the PERSON of DATE on ORG ( “ the DATE LAW ) provided that a creditor had a right to lodge a complaint about excessive length of enforcement proceedings with an authority superior to that carrying them out .

On DATE section CARDINAL of the DATE Act was amended . Under LAW CARDINAL of this provision a person whose legal or factual interest is infringed as a result of non - enforcement of the obligation has a right to lodge a complaint about the length of proceedings . Paragraph CARDINAL provides for an appeal if a complaint is dismissed .
On DATE , the Law of CARDINAL DATE on ORG ( “ the DATE LAW ) entered into force .
Under LAW Act ORG was competent to examine complaints against inactivity on the part of an authority obliged to issue an administrative decision or to carry out enforcement proceedings .
Section CARDINAL of the Act provided :

“ When a complaint alleging inactivity on the part of an administrative authority is well - founded , ORG shall oblige that authority to issue a decision , or to perform a specific act , or to confirm , declare , or recognise a right or obligation provided for by law . ”

Pursuant to LAW , the decision of ORG ordering an authority to put an end to its inactivity was legally binding on the authority concerned . If the authority did not comply with the decision , the court could , under section CARDINAL , impose a fine on it and might itself give a ruling on the right or obligation in question .

LAW was repealed and replaced by LAW DATE on ORG ( “ the DATE Act ” ) which entered into force on DATE . LAW of LAW contains provisions analogous to section CARDINAL of LAW . It provides that administrative courts examine complaints about inactivity on the part of authorities obliged to issue an administrative decision or to carry out enforcement proceedings . Under section CARDINAL , if a complaint is well - founded , an administrative court shall oblige the authority concerned to issue a decision , to perform a specific act , or to confirm , declare , or recognise a right or obligation provided for by law .
